content.title: Membranous Nephropathy
content.summary: Membranous nephropathy (MN) is a leading cause of nephrotic syndrome in adults, characterized by subepithelial immune complex deposits along the glomerular basement membrane. Primary MN is driven by autoantibodies to podocyte antigens (PLA2R in ~70%, THSD7A in ~3%), while secondary causes include malignancy, lupus, hepatitis B, and drugs. Treatment is guided by PLA2R status and risk stratification.
key_points: Most common cause of nephrotic syndrome in white adults
Subepithelial spike-and-dome deposits on electron microscopy
Anti-PLA2R antibodies positive in ~70% of primary MN cases
High spontaneous remission rate (30-40%) justifies initial observation in low-risk patients
Rituximab is first-line immunosuppression for high-risk patients
Screen for secondary causes: malignancy, lupus, HBV, drugs
content.statement: Membranous nephropathy is an autoimmune glomerular disease causing nephrotic syndrome through subepithelial immune complex deposition, diagnosed by biopsy showing basement membrane thickening and spike formation, with anti-PLA2R antibodies serving as a diagnostic and prognostic biomarker.

explanation.intuition: Imagine the glomerular basement membrane as a sieve. In MN, immune complexes deposit on the outside (subepithelial), creating bumps that interfere with filtration. The basement membrane tries to engulf these deposits, creating the characteristic 'spikes' seen on silver stain.
explanation.key_insight: PLA2R antibodies revolutionized MN diagnosis and monitoring: high titers at presentation predict worse outcomes, and falling titers precede clinical remission. This allows targeted, biomarker-guided therapy rather than empiric immunosuppression for all.
explanation.technical_details: Anti-PLA2R IgG4 antibodies bind phospholipase A2 receptor on podocytes, forming in situ immune complexes. Complement activation (C5b-9 membrane attack complex) causes podocyte injury without inflammatory cell infiltration. GBM response produces 'spikes' between deposits visible on Jones methenamine silver stain.

definitions_glossary.membranous_nephropathy: Immune-mediated GN with subepithelial deposits causing nephrotic syndrome
definitions_glossary.PLA2R: Phospholipase A2 receptor; target antigen in ~70% of primary MN
definitions_glossary.THSD7A: Thrombospondin type-1 domain-containing 7A; antigen in ~3% of primary MN
definitions_glossary.subepithelial_deposits: Immune complexes between podocyte and GBM (outside the membrane)
definitions_glossary.spike_and_dome: GBM projections between subepithelial deposits on EM or silver stain
definitions_glossary.spontaneous_remission: Resolution of proteinuria without immunosuppressive treatment
definitions_glossary.anti_PLA2R_antibodies: Circulating autoantibodies diagnostic and prognostic in primary MN
definitions_glossary.immunofluorescence_granular: Granular IgG and C3 staining along capillary loops
definitions_glossary.secondary_MN: MN caused by malignancy, lupus, HBV, drugs rather than primary autoimmunity
definitions_glossary.complement_activation: C5b-9 MAC formation causing podocyte injury in MN
definitions_glossary.rituximab: Anti-CD20 monoclonal antibody; first-line for high-risk primary MN
definitions_glossary.cyclophosphamide: Alkylating agent used in combination regimens for MN

pathophysiology.mechanism: Autoantibody-mediated podocyte injury with subepithelial immune complex formation

PLA2R.significance: Diagnostic marker; titer correlates with disease activity

THSD7A.association: Higher malignancy risk; requires cancer screening

primary_MN.process: Circulating antibodies bind podocyte antigens → in situ immune complex formation → complement activation → podocyte injury → proteinuria

laboratory_findings.complement: C3 and C4 typically normal in primary MN
laboratory_findings.urinalysis: Proteinuria, lipiduria, may have microscopic hematuria

renal_biopsy.light_microscopy: Thickened GBM; GBM spikes on silver stain; no hypercellularity
renal_biopsy.immunofluorescence: Granular IgG and C3 along capillary walls
renal_biopsy.electron_microscopy: Subepithelial electron-dense deposits with GBM spikes

secondary_workup: Age-appropriate malignancy screening (especially if PLA2R negative or >65 years)
SPEP/UPEP if light chain disease suspected

differential_diagnosis: Minimal change disease (another nephrotic syndrome cause)
Lupus nephritis class V (subepithelial deposits but with mesangial deposits)
Diabetic nephropathy (thickened GBM but different clinical context)

low_risk.approach: Conservative management for 6 months; 30-40% spontaneous remission

moderate_risk.approach: Consider immunosuppression if no improvement after 6 months

supportive_care: Anticoagulation if albumin <2.5 g/dL (high thrombosis risk)

rituximab.regimen: 1g IV on days 1 and 15, or 375 mg/m² × 4 weekly
rituximab.evidence: MENTOR trial showed noninferiority to cyclosporine with better durability

cyclophosphamide_steroids.regimen: Ponticelli regimen: alternating monthly steroids and cyclophosphamide × 6 months
cyclophosphamide_steroids.considerations: Higher toxicity but effective; avoid in malignancy

monitoring: Proteinuria monthly initially, then every 3 months

definition.@value: An autoimmune glomerular disease causing nephrotic syndrome through subepithelial immune complex deposition along the glomerular basement membrane

scopeNote.@value: Covers primary and secondary MN, diagnosis including PLA2R antibodies, risk stratification, and treatment with rituximab

medicalCode.description: Isolated proteinuria with diffuse membranous glomerulonephritis

learning_objectives: Describe the pathogenesis of primary MN involving anti-PLA2R antibodies
Interpret renal biopsy findings including subepithelial deposits and GBM spikes
Identify secondary causes of MN requiring specific screening
Apply risk stratification to guide treatment decisions
Select appropriate immunosuppression for high-risk MN patients
clinical_pearls: PLA2R-negative MN in patient >65 years: screen aggressively for malignancy
Falling PLA2R titers precede clinical remission by months - useful for monitoring
High spontaneous remission rate justifies 6-month observation in low-risk patients
Anticoagulate if albumin <2.5 g/dL due to high thrombotic risk
Rituximab is now first-line: better than cyclosporine for sustained remission (MENTOR)
common_misconceptions: All MN needs immunosuppression - no, 30-40% remit spontaneously
Subepithelial deposits always mean MN - lupus class V also has subepithelial deposits
PLA2R negative means secondary MN - some primary MN is PLA2R negative
